newsitem.title: FRANCE: France calls Mideast summit "hour of truth".
newsitem.headline: France calls Mideast summit "hour of truth".

text.p: French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette described the Washington Middle East summit on Wednesday as "the hour of truth," saying the key to peace was in the hands of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

"If the road to peace is to be resumed, the necessary steps must be taken: settle the fate of Hebron, return to the previous situation regarding the (Jerusalem) tunnel, withdraw tanks surrounding the West Bank's autonomous (Palestinian) towns," he told the National Assembly.
"France expects a lot from the Washington meeting," he said, adding that the peace process could resume only on the basis of the Israeli-Palestinian accords.
He said France and Europe could be relied upon in the quest for peace and were attentive to Israel's yearning for security and the Palestinians's concerns for peace and independence.
The European Union has sharply rebuked Netanyahu for failing to meet Israel's obligations in the Middle East peace process.
De Charette recalled that President Jacques Chirac would in the coming weeks embark on an extensive tour of the Middle East to reaffirm France's presence. He gave no date for the trip.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Yasser Arafat met for three hours on Tuesday at the crisis summit called by President Bill Clinton after bloody clashes between Palestinians and Israelis last week threatened to scuttle the whole peace process.
